comments.commentBody: WNYC was a public radio station.

The mean-spiritedness comes from those who haven't had their basic needs met, and that's not in terms of milk, bread and honey.   We're speaking of a lack of love, caring and happiness in their lives and in their circumstances.  Have you seen people who "get it"?  They hug each other whenever they get off the bus or train, no matter how tough their day had been.  There's a grace in their souls that no disaster, man made or otherwise, can ever take away.

"Decisions are made by those who show up."
[Martin Sheen in character as Pres. Bartlet on the TV show, "The West Wing."]

Not voting - Is voting...to keep the screwed-up and dysfunctional status quo. Declining to vote is eschewing the chance at change, even if having to hold the nose while filling out the ballot. (Granting and granted, Nixon's resignation soured a lot of folks on politics, many made speedily recoveries after Carter got elected however)
I would never, ever urge anyone to vote. By all means, sit this one out and leave it to those who feel strongly about it. But don't complain about the result!

What I've done in my mind is choose the one most likely to do a good job for the country.  Based on experience, record, and evident ability to work with others who will be a part of government, that person among all those seeking the office is Hillary Clinton.  In fact, that was not a hard decision, though I like Sander's positions.  He, like Cruz, has a hard time working with others.

Trump looks and sounds disgusting. He's an angry man that hates everyone. So we change the TV when he appears. Then we change the TV when Hillary Clinton appears. And we change when Sanders or Cruz come on. What is one supposed to do when the likely contenders for the Presidency are all unworthy of the Office?

Oh my. It all makes my head spin to think that one of these people on their way to the top of their respective pile will be our President. I feel extremely uneasy voting for any of them. Is this the best we can do as a nation? I think not. But so much must change if the dignity can return. And just to be clear, I do not favor the Tea Party or the group that has control over politics at the moment. Stating that a great deal must change doesn't mean I'd like to shut down the government or get rid of everyone and all the laws.

But I haven’t had the urge to vote since about 1976. Looking at the news, I am not likely to do so in the near future either. Thank you for your time in reading this.

Sorry but your opinion, especially since it's the interior and not the exterior of the house, matters not to the past or current owners. It's none of your business if you neither were selling or intending to buy it. It's just personal taste if there are no regulations applying to that property which says that certain aspects must be maintained. And I say this as someone who loves all types of architecture/ built-ins and lives in the Bay area.

Here in San Francisco, the house next door to me was lovely, old-fashioned, all wood, built-in bookcases, etc. They ruined it by gutting the entire interior and making it "modern". It sickens me to think what they did to that house. Just to up the price.... Now I have to live next door to the people who bought it. Yuck.
Crested Beauticians have no quarrel with Buffalonians.
Most of the year, they're Buffalonians, but during a blizzard, they're Buffaloafers.

Some day you might be shoveling  snow  and get a heart attack or die in a car accident. You must be in a  bad place to think another person death  isn't a bad thing. Because of the sin of large  carbon foot print? Find yourself a different religion. You know one with compassion for others.

I might have been more creative when naming residents of Buffalo “Buffalonians”.

But when I read cautionaries about excessive activity during blizzards I can’t help considering an exploding global population in the teeth of global climate change that is tied to the industrial activity and waste products of billions of human beings. Consider what staying indoors for days might mean in the inevitable appearance nine months later of an excessive cohort of “Baffalonians”, all of them eventually driving big SAVs (suburban assault vehicles) and eating beef, requiring coal-fired electricity and generally creating so many additional carbon footprints simply by breathing in and out for eighty or ninety years.

In this light, are heart attacks from over-exertion and car-crash fatalities ALL bad?

It takes wisdom accumulated through the years for intellect to temper youthful idealism.

Acknowledging that some still do not - it is fervently believed that most of the "American population" knows full well exactly what is implied and expected when "civility" is mentioned...even though some habitually eschew it.
Since 32% respond to pollsters that they support Trump, and essentially none say they don't know, then 68% don't support him.  Is that too hard to recognize as a "significant majority"?

By the 68% percent majority, the authors must be suggesting that their interviewees are approximately that age.  Best I can tell, the youngest interviewee featured in the article is 63, which is hardly representative of the population at large.  It certainly falls short of a claim that "the significant majority of Republican voters here [are] immune to Mr. Trump's charms...."  If "civility" is truly a meaningful consideration, a broader understanding of what the American population expects of that term is necessary.

Maybe 10 years ago. Today, pollsters are well aware of cell phone usage and how to contact people to get a distribution of responses that reflect the population.

(That being said: most polls are slanted to get the results the pollsters would prefer....it is easy to twist questions...i.e., "have you stopped beating your wife?".)

NOTE: the idea that "old folks" have landlines and not cellphones is really outdated. All my senior relatives (over 80) have and use only cellphones. The AARP sells cellphones. It is not just young people who use them -- not anymore.

This really scares me because it is so delusional. How could he possibly think that even most Democrats would put this plan into effect, let alone Republicans? I don't condemn the idea of a single payer, but making such vast changes in American health care needs full cooperation from all concerned - not only including politicians but physicians, big pharma, and the whole list of people who now benefit from the current system. The reason I'm scared is because he stands a chance of being nominated as the Democratic presidential nominee. This plan will guarantee putting a Republican in office. Can you imagine the party Republicans would have with this?

What people say and what they do are not the same things.

Often polls about election results are quite wrong. What happens inside the secrecy of the voting booth is still secret, and that's a good thing.

It is widely accepted, on both sides of the aisle, that Sarah Palin SUNK the McCain campaign.

The idea that another candidate would choose a proven loser -- who made a fool of herself in public every time she opened her mouth -- is beyond ridiculous.

well, of course!
misogyny is an even greater prejudice than racism.

@Marie: if Mr. Trump ALSO wins twice, will YOU get over it?

Were you super polite and non-critical of former POTUS GW Bush? because most liberals still can't over hating on him. Bush was also elected TWICE.

Just remember: what goes round, comes round.

Honestly Rand Paul is the most rational of the bunch, but Republicans know that it makes no sense to float an unelectable anti-bank, anti-war, 4th amendment advocate, which is why he's at 4%.

Republicans are irrational leaders, but they make up for it in electoral savvy.
I agree.

Wow, I was very unimpressed by this recipe. Followed it to a tee too. Wouldn't make it again. The only reason I gave it one star was because the skin was delicious. Seemed like a glorified pesto chicken. Yes it was moist as is all the chicken I cook. Very disappointed.
Beware. Mr Putin appears to be smart, in-charge and ruthless. His jujitsu track record and philosophy shows he will be seeking a "third" way to outsmart and game the west. He's dangerous.
THANK you. Well said. And needed.

Every time time there's a MAJOR snowstorm on the east coast, you'd think the entire Midwest forgets how the population count is much higher and the transportation systems are more complicated on the east coast, says anyone who's been to NY or Philly or Boston or DC.
It is said that the scammers of IOS (way back then) did just the reverse. Their claim was to make you a millionaire.  Later we found out that they were speaking to billionaires.

That wasn't Martin's joke, your version of the set-up isn't funny.

How to be a millionaire: first, get a million dollars.

Obvious.
In the music business the way to make a million dollars is to start with two million.

It would be fun to go back to 2012 and tell Old Mittens Romney that just like in 2012, in 2016 there would also be a famous millionaire businessman Republican nominee that doesn’t particularly believe anything he says and was also willing to say anything to prove the point….and his name would be Trumpolini ---- the expression on Mitten’s face would be heavenly.

Mittens was a good dealmaker, too, just like Trumpolini.

Mitt made his money slicing and dicing companies and selling off the body parts for a handsome premium.

The Donald made his money by gambling with house money and his dad's money on casinos and real estate.

Both Mittens and The Donald struggled financially in their early years.

Who can forget the painful account Ann Romney offered about hers and Mitt's financially difficult college years.

“They were not easy years…neither one of us had a job, but Mitt had enough of an investment from stock that we could sell off a little at a time. The stock came from Mitt’s father..when he took over American Motors...Mitt cashed it in so we could live and pay for education.”

And poor Donald has told us: "It has not been easy for me, it has not been easy for me. And you know I started off in Brooklyn, my father gave me a small loan of a million dollars."

(Tissue break !)

The Republican Party in 2012 and 2016 has offered Americans two of the finest struggling millionaires in history.

How can Americans not support these two fine Horatio Alger political weathervanes ?

It's got to be an early night. We're up early to do arrangements in San Francisco tomorrow morning. It's no trip to the moon but the weather has been wonderfully nasty so we have to leave extra time.

I hope we get to declare the drought over.
Ben, you are the BEST!

Oh Toutes, give it a rest.

How about some personal responsibility ?

If liberals made things easy for you, you would't have any incentive to succeed, now would you ?
I had to reduce the heat in this recipe. 500 degrees and the chicken was smoking so much, my smoke alarm went off - even with a good fan.
I agree.
L: It had been the home of William James. I'd have thought that would be some protection, but apparently not.
Sarah and L:  William James?? Good Lord that makes me weep, talk about 'whitewashing the past'.

Oh, no. This is a tragedy. Perhaps if the community of James scholars had known the house was on the market, something could have been done. Sarah, when did this happen?

http://society.wjsociety.org
http://www.american-philosophy.org

With the *possible* exception of the narrow bedroom with brick walls toward the end -- and even then it's iffy -- the "before" pictures were snazzier and far more interesting than the vapid, watered-down whiteness of the staged versions.

In my old neighborhood, the gorgeous built-in bookcases of a quietly beautiful historical house were ripped out in order to "upgrade" and make the house look "fresh and new." So sad and vexing, because so unnecessary.
Finally, someone reporting it like it is—the Goodell/Wells partnership was the real conspiracy.
